newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan court slaps 'sokaiya' with 5-month jail term.
newsitem.headline: Japan court slaps 'sokaiya' with 5-month jail term.

text.p: A Japanese court on Monday sentenced a "sokaiya" racketeer to five months in prison for extorting money from Ajinomoto Co Inc, the nation's top processed food maker.
In his ruling at the Tokyo District Court, chief judge Kiyoshi Kimura said racketeer Chosei Wada received two million yen ($17,094) from an Ajinomoto executive in December 1995.
Ajinomoto paid the cash to the racketeer in return for ensuring that the company's shareholders meetings ran smoothly, Kimura said.
"This is a vicious crime in which the accused ignored the spirit of the revised Commercial Code," Kimura said.
Japan's Commercial Code, revised in 1993, bans companies from making payments to sokaiya, who extort money from companies by threatening to disrupt shareholder meetings.
Chief judge Kimura also blamed Ajinomoto for bowing to pressure from the racketeer.
"The problem also rests to a considerable degree with the company itself, which succumbed to pressure from the sokaiya," he said.
In April, Ajinomoto said its president Shunsuke Inamori would resign over the scandal, in which two company officials were arrested and indicted on suspicion of making illegal payments to sokaiya.

Monday's ruling comes at a time when two top Japanese financial firms, Nomura Securities Co Ltd and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd (DKB), are facing fierce public and government criticism for making huge payoffs to racketeers.
A dozen top executives at Nomura and DKB, as well as the companies themselves, have been charged with giving cash or loans to a racketeer.
The Finance Ministry is soon expected to unveil administrative penalties against Nomura and DKB for their admitted payoffs to racketeer Ryuichi Koike. ($1=117 yen)
